name: Gargantua
description: A supermassive black hole, serving as a significant location in the film 'Interstellar'.

content.title: History
content.body: Gargantua was formed naturally in the universe and discovered by humans as a potential gateway for exploring neighboring galaxies. Its discovery is pivotal for the missions depicted in 'Interstellar', as it offers potential solutions to Earth's ecological crisis.

content.title: Geography
content.body: Gargantua is a visually striking supermassive black hole with an accretion disk of superheated matter orbiting it. It is situated in a distant galaxy, with its surrounding planets and singular gravitational pull making it a hub for scientific exploration.

content.title: Notable Features
content.body:
- **Accretion Disk**: The disk emits intense radiation and energy, creating a unique visual effect around Gargantua.
- **Event Horizon**: The boundary marking the point of no return, beyond which even light cannot escape.
- **Time Dilation**: The immense gravitational pull of Gargantua causes significant time dilation, affecting the aging process for those close to it.

content.title: Story Significance
content.body: Gargantua is central to the plot of 'Interstellar'. It acts as a gateway for the Endurance crew's mission to find habitable planets. The black hole's gravitational properties, particularly time dilation, play a crucial role in the narrative, affecting the characters' relationships and decisions.
